âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Perfect for clash

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good job on constructing this puzzle!

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple and straightforward clash :)

Nice clash :) I'm surprised no one has done this before.

- To make the wording clearer, please rephrase "not on the edges of the list" to something like "the peak must have element(s) on its left and right".

- Again for clarity, "value is bigger than the one before..." -> "the peak is <<strictly larger>> than its adjacent elements (the elements directly to its left and right)".

- Consider incorporating the idea of mountain heights into your clash. Otherwise, the inclusion of mountain heights seems somewhat redundant, as it is not used anywhere else in your clash.

- This clash is suitable for Fastest mode as well, if you would like to enable that mode too :) I'm not too sure about Reverse mode.

All sections
* Please format all variables.

Goal
* Please rewrite the two bullet points conditions in plain English, e.g. describing a peak as an element with neighbors on both sides that is strictly higher than both of them. This makes the statement sound less like code, and avoids unintentionally giving implementation hints.

Constraints
* Please use ranges that better reflect the actual ones used in the test cases, hence
  â€¢ Change 1000 to 100.
  â€¢ Change -10^9 to 1.
  â€¢ Change 10^9 to 100.

Stub generator
* Please change "h" to "ai" for consistency.

Cases
* Validator 5
  â€¢ Please remove the trailing newline from the input.
  â€¢ Please use a few more integers from the range 10 to 100 in the input.

Thanks.
Thanks for the feedback! I think i implemented everything you suggested :)
I think you might have accidentally duplicated the last line of your goal. Looks good otherwise :)

Thank you for the update. Here are my comments on your revised contribution:

Goal
* Please change "position [[i]]" to "element".

Cases
* Some input elements in Test 6 exceed 100, so the case violates the new upper limit. Please revise the case. (Reverting the upper limit to 1000 wouldn't be a good solution unless you also revise more cases to include in input a balanced distribution of values between 100 and 1000.)
Thanks for the insight, went a little above with the numbers hahah!
No worries, it looks fine now ðŸ˜‰
